Juul Labs gave to members of Congress, attorneys general ahead of midterms

With Sarah Cammarata and Daniel Lippman

JUUL GAVE TO MEMBERS OF CONGRESS, ATTORNEYS GENERAL AHEAD OF MIDTERMS: PI has reported on the bevy of lobbying firms hired by Juul Labs in recent months as the vaping company has faced regulatory scrutiny, including Covington & Burling, Empire Consulting Group, InSight Public Affairs, Kountoupes Denham Carr & Reid and the S-3 Group.

PROSECUTORS INVESTIGATING LOBBYING OFFSHOOTS OF MUELLER INVESTIGATION: From The New York Times’ Adam Goldman and Mark Mazzetti: “Federal prosecutors in Virginia are investigating a secret Turkish lobbying effort that once involved Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser, even as Mr. Flynn’s role in the special counsel’s investigation winds down, according to people familiar with the inquiry.

… Many specifics of the Virginia investigation are unclear, but it could involve whether anyone associated with Mr. Flynn or his company failed to comply with the Foreign Agents Registration Act, the law requiring disclosures to the Justice Department about lobbying on behalf of foreign interests.” Flynn already admitted to the special counsel that he violated FARA.

— At the same time, “Justice Department prosecutors in the last several weeks have begun interviewing witnesses and contacting lawyers to schedule additional questioning related to the Podesta Group and Mercury Public Affairs, the people familiar with the inquiry said,” The Associated Press’ Eric Tucker, Desmond Butler and Chad Day report.

MEANWHILE, IN NEW YORK: “Some of the nation’s top insurance companies, including MassMutual, Pacific Life and Prudential, quietly fought to dilute a robust revision of a New York state regulation designed to protect consumers from unscrupulous sales practices involving retirement savings products,” POLITICO’s Patrick Temple-West reports.

“Over the last few months, we have grown our D.C. team to engage with lawmakers, regulators, public health officials and advocates to drive awareness of our mission to improve the lives of the world's one billion smokers and to combat underage use so we keep Juul out of the hands of young people,” Davis said in a statement.
